snippet.textDisplay: Thank you for much for sharing this. I was a JW my entire life until 1.5 years ago when I was disfellowshipped. I was so involved I was even a pioneer for awhile. My mom found out I had sex before marriage but what she didn't know is that it was rape. I was kicked out almost immediately after she told the elders without my consent. It was the worst experience of my life as I felt my life was over and all of my childhood friends were just instantly gone. I was shunned by almost everyone I knew. I wasn't allowed to get advanced education especially for something that they considered a "man's field" but now I'm an aerospace engineer major.  I always had to "know my place as the lesser being." It was degrading at times. Not having a mom to talk to was the worst of it. I could never trust her because anything I'd tell her she'd immediately tell someone else or the elders. They always meant more to her. Thank you for showing me that I am not alone in this. You and I are lucky, we have our freedom that they tried to take away and we can only hope that the real light will be shed on them and they are able to escape. They're the blind ones, not us. Stay strong Hannah I'm rooting for you.

snippet.textDisplay: I think as children we hold our parent’s on a pedestal. We hope that they’ll be there for the big moments whether it is a graduation or wedding. Even when we know they won’t be there, we still feel hurt when they aren’t there. Even though they are toxic for your life we want them to be there because you love them. You want to share these moments with the people you love. That is not wrong and that is not bad. While your dad has chosen to cut you off and you may continue to love him, you are not wrong. You can still love him but still move on with your life and choose not have a relationship with him. Should he ever want to continue to a relationship, he will need to work hard to catch up with you.

snippet.textDisplay: I’m out to most of my family and I’m proud of who i am. The only people who don’t know are my aunt, uncle, and grandma because they are all Jehovah’s Witnesses. I grew up going to their hall and district conventions. I remember going to a District convention when I was in seventh grade. It was right after I had came out to most of my friends and family. I remember sitting there and halfway through the man speaking said “all gays will be damned to hell”. That’s the day I decided I was not going with them anymore. I’m still close with them and I love them I just don’t think I’ll be able to come out to them anytime soon because I’m scared of losing them.

snippet.textDisplay:
I can’t imagine what this feels like. I’m about as basic a white straight man as you’ll get. Heck I’m even religious (Christian). But I DO understand what it’s like to not have a relationship with your dad and wonder if it’s your fault. Spending your days wondering why he seems to just overlook you. Not really ignore, but just kinda not really be there. It sucks.

It’s definitely not your fault. It’s not up to the child to “conform” to what the parent wants. You can be guided, helped, but ultimately you determine your life. I was fortunate my dad learned this and began to accept my lifestyle choices that were so far from his. He chose to still love me, despite those differences. He decided to choose family.

(No I’m not throwing the “homosexuality is a choice BS. Don’t do that please.)

But so many times parents don’t. And I can’t imagine what that feels like and I’m so sorry. It’s natural that you want to have a good relationship with your dad. That’s 100% valid. That pain is valid. It shows you have a good heart. Lean on those you know support you. Your mom, your fiancé, your loved ones who chose you. ❤️

snippet.textDisplay: I'm so sorry to you, Hannah, and to everyone in the comments going through things like this. Reading so many similar stories is heartbreaking. It's hard enough being rejected by family for just being who you are, but I can't imagine adding in the religious trauma and having to rebuild your core beliefs back up brick by brick into something healthy. I hope you all know that it's okay to hate them for what they've done to you. It's okay to admit they're bad parents and part of bad organizations. They've given you no respect, so you have no obligation to give it back in kind. They betrayed you and don't deserve you, even if you more than deserved what they were supposed to give you. Stay strong. I'm proud of you. <3

snippet.textDisplay: It is very very sad and a deeper pain than I could ever imagine. Perhaps the best thing I could advise is to remember  that one part of getting married is that you are not just celebrating the love between you and your beloved, you are also forming a brand new family. You bring into that process all the joy, love, and pain from your life into that creation. Your new family may grow, it may remain as it is was the day you get married - it is YOURS and no one else can take that from you. Your  family is what you  make it - and while you grieve that your father is not who he should be, you can take joy from what you do have. So mourn, cry, and do what you need to have a great wedding.

snippet.textDisplay: Though I can not empathize to the same level, my whole life my father has proven over and over again that he can only be around when it's convenient for him. He left before I even turned one and for years I only really knew his face through photos. Then after about eight years he slowly started to come back into my brother and I's lives. But whenever it became innconvient to have us (he wanted to do something that would be hindered by kids) he would drop us off back at our moms place, or not pick us up, if it was his turn to take us. I'm happy that my stepmom has helped him through the years become a better father. Now having their own child (my wonderful half sister), I worry constantly that he might disappear on her and break yet another family. But I am so thankful for my mom and stepdad that were always there for my brother and I, even when it got difficult.

Did she delete my comment?? I wrote a paragraph lol where is my comment I can’t find it. I want to edit it!!

I was going to say: If you are experiencing negative emotional stress & feeling isolated and indifferent, you need to go to a different place of worship. I keep seeing comments of people judging the entire religion based on that 1 community, theres 100,000s’ many more out there. You cant base 1 horrible experience on the entire religion. That does not define everyone or the religion. People are so blind it’s crazy how one-sides things can be. Some in the religion are more extreme than others, & some are more helpful and supportive than others. A cult is run by a person & made up based on a false religion coming from 1 person’s form of beliefs. The JW’s are a branch of Christianity and believe in Jesus, who is Gods son. They worship 1 GOD. They DO NOT worship a man. They read a PUBLISHED BIBLE. (Have you ever seen Midsommar that movie was great & that movie is a CULT).

I didnt read the description and its extremely sad, someone as yourself is posting something about a widespread religion because of something you’re personally going through based on 1 teeny weeny part of the entire community. You have 2 million subscribers and im assuming you’re an influencer? Of the sorts idk never heard of you until i saw an article on snapchat. You know what it said? “Anti LGBT religious group” , JW’s are not anti LGBT GROUP. They do not actively hate or hurt anyone. They dont go out in public or talk amongst themselves and hate talk anyone of such. They are not the KKK of LGBT. Now THAT IS a hate group. Just because you’re father and family is treating you like that, you have no right being so blind and disrespectful to such religion. Where as you’re influencing the negativity and not the positivity. Something the LGBT doesn’t stand for, which is negativity. Just because you have a bad experience doesn’t define the entirety of the JW’s religion or who the people are. If a dog bites you, are you going to judge all dogs as malicious biters? No. You aren’t. So why are you being so ignorant and insensitive to the JW group by posting such a crazy controversial video. You just had to talk about your feelings not go in entirely to the details of said religion. If you were Jewish and posting something like this you would probably be getting hate. JW’s also got sent to camps by Hitler. JW’s are like a branch of Jews. Did you know that? I hope you read this so you can see how bad you acted on the situation. That description is completely unnecessary. You’re fighting hate and rejection and its one sided since JW’s cannot defend themselves on the media. Its also very hypocritical of you. You’re not the only one facing troubles right now. Your mom and father are as well. This video kinda shows how blind you are. What about his feelings? You know he is an elder and know how strict he is with his religious beliefs. ITS HIS BELIEF. Its who he is. Kind of how you’re a lesbian. It goes both ways, not just 1. You both need to come to an understanding with each other and not just sit behind a camera and play victim. You took everything out of play by accusing the entire JW of such actions. Very selfish and a wrong thing to do. If anything thats sinister of you, considering someone who influences people. You’re just fighting that rejection and putting your anger on millions of people who are JW’s. Calling it a cult when a cult can barely grow past 100k people or even waaayy less than that.

My best friend from high school died a few years ago due to JW beliefs. Her husband and her had tried to have a baby for years, and she finally got pregnant with TWIN girls! They were so excited and she was over the moon, she couldn’t wait to be a mother. During the delivery by c-section there were complications and she lost a lot of blood and required a blood transfusion. Due to their beliefs they turned down the transfusion and she died. She got to hold her babies once and then she was gone. Her husband has since remarried and they are raising the girls. They look just like my beautiful friend. It breaks my heart knowing that her death could have been easily prevented.

I’m sorry you are hurting, Hannah. But you are right, this is not your fault and you have nothing to be ashamed of. Your father is the one that is missing out. Much love to you 💜

snippet.textDisplay: I’m too young to think about getting married at the moment (17).  When I do, I will happily marry another woman and enjoy a healthy lesbian relationship.  While my parents say that they accept me now, I’ve been through some toxic moments.  I have plenty of time to think about it, but my cousin didn’t invite his parents to his wedding (his mom showed up anyway), and rather than risk being told I’m “perverted” or “confused” for loving someone, I’m considering the same thing.  This gives me the strength to give second chances to family members, but not to pour my heart into it or expect drastic changes.  Thank you.

snippet.textDisplay:
My parents haven't been in my life for years (mom since 2011, dad since 2016). Most of the time I'm fine with it, and I've never regretted my choice to cut them out. But I've learned there will always be times when I am sad that I don't have their parental love...because parents are supposed to be the ones who love you unconditionally. And when they don't, it hurts.


There's so much love in my life without them, and I know there's so much love in your life too. We ARE all worthy of love. Even when the people who are supposed to give us love freely can't or won't or don't.


None of us are alone. And Hannah, thanks for making this video. I'm so happy you get to spend a day celebrating love with people who love you. <3

snippet.textDisplay: My parents didn’t come to my wedding. Why didn’t they come? They are jehovah witnesses and I am not. Only way they’d support me or be in my life is if I pretended to believe in their god and go to their church and be active in their church. I was sad they didn’t come but ultimately came to realize they gave me the gift of those absence. My wedding was full of love and acceptance. Many guests commented on what wonderful loving friends and family (who are non jw)we have. If parents came it would have diluted that love. They would have brought their condescension and self-righteousness. I really don’t need that in my life. I am sorry that you’re hurting and that you don’t have the relationship with your father that you want. Focus on all the love that you do have in your life. Focus on the people who except you and love you for who you are and don’t want to change you. I’m not saying Do not be sad. Sadness and hurt is the appropriate reaction to how your father is treating you

snippet.textDisplay: It's so much more important to build a wall of love around you than to keep someone around who cannot really love you because of who they are. snippet.textDisplay:
Hannah,
You said you don't know why you're shocked that he's not going. That it has always been that way, that he's always chosen the Witnesses over you/your truth. It is normal to always hope that things will be different. That one day they will value you the way they should, that they will love you correctly, that they will accept you. And it's disappointing every time they fail to do those things. Big life moments (engagements, weddings, babies, etc.) are when this love and support matters the most. You have hope that one day he will do better. Especially with all you have done and accomplished. I know you know this, but the fault is within him. It is within their bigoted way of thinking. You are love and light and truth. Keep spreading it, babe. You matter. You are beautiful. You are enough.
We love you. Exactly as you are.
-Nat

snippet.textDisplay: @MyHarto if someone doesnt want to be at your wedding, I understand it is painful because they are important to you, and you want to share your special moment with them. However, I have learned through similar experiences that this can be a painful blessing in disguise. They are letting you know right at the start where you lie on their priority list. You have reached out to them and they made the choice to pull back. This is not on you, and I doubt there is anything you really did to make them come to this choice. This is about them. As hard as it will be, the best thing you can do is focus on those who want to be in your life, and hope those who dont will change their mind. If they dont, that is their choice, but dont let them rob you of your joy, especially at this time when you are beginning a new chapter of your life. Those who want to be in your life will, and those who dont want to be in your life will cause distress in yours until you let them go. The most important thing now is your future together with your spouse. Dont let family, freinds, coworkers, or anyone else put themselves as more important than you and your spouse. I wish I did that long ago, trying to keep them in my life against their will has caused me alot of ruin. So with all that said, I wish you and your spouse all the best in life and marriage, and congratulations!

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm an ex-JW as well, molested by my brother-in-law who is a ministerial servant, my mother basically threatened me to keep quiet about it, and when I married my Jewish husband, my sister (wife of the molester) refused to attend. While I'm glad her husband was far, far away from me, I was devastated that my sister and her kids wouldn't come. My mother attended, but she basically hid the fact from the elders. My father and brother thankfully never joined the cult. I got out in my early 20s. My sister and I were very close, despite being 6 years apart. I admired her more than I can say, she was beautiful, inventive, hard-working, and a moral goal in my childhood. I was her bridesmaid at a very conservative JW wedding in a Kingdom Hall. I babysat her kids, practically raised them from birth to age seven. Learning she was boycotting my wedding because of my husband's religion, and then having her completely cut off all communication with me for five years, devastated me.

My sister refused to let her kids come to the wedding too, and I had planned to have my niece as the flower girl. (I knew no other young girls.) I practically raised those kids while she worked, I adore them, I honed in the interests and talent that they are now pursuing as teenagers. My nephew's obsession with technology? That was my husband's doing, back when we were dating, and we'd take my nephew to car shows and science museums, places his parents had no interest in.

At one point, my mom managed an intervention of sorts, tricking my sister into letting me into her home so I could meet the kids. I gave my nephew my email because he wanted to write to me. I got one letter from him, and then nothing. My pervert brother-in-law blocked my email, and blocked me from all online games my nephew and I used to play together, and then told my nephew that I was a terrible person for ghosting him.

Then last week, my mom told me that my niece is in therapy due to that molester brother-in-law of mine mentally and emotionally torturing her, purposefully dressing her in hideous outfits although my mom bought her cute dresses, screaming at her if she dared pick her own outfit for the day, and once he punched a hole through the wall because my sister dared tried to defend her daughte and told him to back off. After that violent outburst, she never defended her children again. My niece now suffers from the same mentally health problems that nearly ended my life, all due to Jehovah's Witnesses.

I desperately want to reach out to her before she attempts suicide like I did, but I was 100% cut off. Even family who are Jehovah's Witnesses but live in other states are not given the phone numbers or emails of the kids.

When my father had a heart attack and my sister was in charge of informing the family. It was the first time in three years that I have heard her voice, and I had this moment of great hope that she had changed. Her call to me went, "Dad had a heart attack, Mom wanted me to tell the family. I called you LAST." And she hung up before I could say a word. She didn't call me again for seven years.

Recently, when my brother who never joined the cult was kicked out of the home by his wife, suddenly divorced and homeless and pleaded with my sister to let him camp in her backyard until he could find an apartment (they are the only two family members in California) she refused. He asked three times! So much for Christian charity. He was in dire need, but she didn't like that he was a divorcee and not a JW.

While there's some solace in knowing you're not alone, it's also disgusting that so many have suffered through this, all in the name of a god. Being cut off from family hurts. It's a pain that never completely goes away.

I still hold hope that my sister might wake up one day, divorce that abusive #MeToo poster boy, and I sincerely want my niece and nephew to seek me out when they are no longer under the grinding thumb of the church... but I know it's hard to leave them. Like a cult, they are taught to excommunicate you, don't let them into your home, don't call them on the phone, don't have anything to do with the Apostate.

It's not my fault. It's not YOUR fault. It's something JWs have to answer for to God, maybe they are reborn as a cockroach for being so awful toward family, although my Agnostic self says they'll just have to live with the guilt, if there is any. How brainwashed JWs are, I don't there's a single drop off guilt as they cut off friends and family who don't want to serve Jehovah.

It hurts, take care of yourself, talk it out. Talking helps. Hugs!

snippet.textDisplay:
"I put my sexual perversion ahead of my family, and to my enormous surprise, my very pious father objected".
You strike me as somebody who lives in a fantasy world. If you knew anything about your father at all, based on your lifetime of exposure to him, you could certainly forsee this. You want to make a video to display your "victimhood" to the world.
If you genuinely thought your Jehovah's Witness parent would attend your lesbian wedding, you know very little about your own father and about the religion he has devoted himself to. You are like a spoiled child, you want a relationship with your father and yet you know it's impossible (or should know) based on the lifestyle you've chosen.
You say you want a relationship with your father, so you can portray yourself as the injured party. But how can you genuinely "want a relationship" with someone you fundamentally misunderstand?
Your infantile perspective I find embarrassing and ridiculous

i'm really sorry about your dad choosing a destructive and manipulative cult over his amazing daughter, but honestly, if he can't even come to your wedding, then he isn't worth your time and energy.

my mother grew up in the same cult, and since she often questioned it, she was faced with both hatred and threats. the more she distanced herself from j.w, the more they tried to intimidate, control and manipulate her. although her mother came to her wedding, their relationship remained destructive. so after a long journey of being free from drugs, she cut off contact with her mother(and siblings) and is now feeling better than ever. she grieves it sometimes and then we talk about it, but she knows deep down that leaving j.w and all the destructive relationships behind is the best thing she could have done.

so lots of hugs to the both of you <3
